legal_basis: Notice is given under section 1 of the Statistics of Trade Act 1947.
title: Annual Survey of Hours and Earnings (ASHE)

title.text: You are completing this for {ru_name} {trad_as}

description.text: If the company details or structure have changed contact us on {telephone_number_link} or email {email_link}

list: You have been selected to complete the Annual Survey of Hours and Earnings (ASHE).
ASHE is based on a sample of employees in the United Kingdom and uses the national tax register as its sampling frame.
In order to achieve the most accurate year on year comparisons and to minimise the sample size, we select the same named individuals each year.
Information should be recorded for all employees if they still work for the organisation.
You cannot appeal your selection. The organisation was selected to give us a comprehensive view of the UK economy.
We will treat your data securely and confidentially.
You still need to complete this survey even if it does not seem relevant. All returns are important as it helps us produce better statistics.
You can provide informed estimates if actual figures are not available.
You can save or print a copy of your answers for your records at the end of this questionnaire.

contents.description: View the survey information and questions before you start the survey (this link opens in a new tab)
This survey covers the following topics:

description.text: You will be asked to confirm if the person named was an employee in the organisation on {reference_date}.

contents.description: A specific date in April is chosen so that all respondents refer to the same point in time. This reference date is not the same every year.
You will be asked for details of the employee’s job, specifically their:
You will be asked to check the employee’s workplace and home postcodes are correct. If they are not, you will be asked to provide the correct information.
The home postcode question is voluntary.
You will be asked to provide information for the employee’s earnings and hours worked, including:

list: any absences or reduced rate in pay

contents.description: These questions are for Occupational Pension Schemes that are set up by employers to provide pensions and/or life assurance benefits for employees when they retire from work.
You will be asked for information on current membership and contributions to any pension scheme run or facilitated by the organisation. This includes:

list: automatic enrollment on a workplace pension

description.text: For all questions on pension arrangements, your answers should relate to the pay period that included {reference_date}.

contents.description: Pension information should generally be available on an employee’s pay and/or personnel records. If pension arrangements are organised by an insurance company, you should obtain the details from them.

description.text: You will be asked for annual information related to the tax year ending {tax_year_end_date}. This includes:

contents.description: You will be asked for the employee’s paid annual leave entitlement.
You will be asked for information on the employee’s pay agreement.

description.text: If the employee was not employed on {reference_date} you will be asked for information on the employee’s history with the organisation.

list: This survey provides the most comprehensive source of information on the structure and distribution of earnings in the UK.
The results of the survey provide an estimate of the levels, distribution and make-up of earnings which are used by Government, employers and other interested parties.
View the latest publication produced from this survey (this link opens in a new tab)

title.text: Employee Details for {employee_employeename}

blocks.page_title: Employee details

title.text: Employee Details for {employee_employeename}

contents.description: This section relates to the employment information of the following individual, who should be employed by the organisation:

National Insurance Number: {employee_nationalinsurancenumberstarred}
Works number, branch, department: {employee_workid}

contents.description: Employment information includes:
View further guidance and a glossary of terms with definitions used throughout the questionnaire (this link opens in a new tab).

title.text: On {reference_date}, was the following person a paid employee in your organisation working in the United Kingdom and receiving a salary or a wage?

description.text:
Employee name: {employee_employeename}

National Insurance Number: {employee_nationalinsurancenumberstarred}

Works number, branch, department: {employee_workid}

contents.description: Include:

list: employees being paid despite being absent for reasons such as, but not limited to, sickness and maternity or paternity leave. For these employees, the remainder of the questionnaire should be filled in about the job from which they were absent

contents.description: Examples of what to exclude:

list: a company director who does not receive a salary

contents.description: This refers to England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland but excludes the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man.

options.label: Yes
No

blocks.page_title: Employee’s status at your organisation

title.text: When did {employee_employeename} start working for the organisation?

description:
If the employee has worked in another part of the organisation, or the organisation has changed ownership since the employee first joined, the start date should be the date when they first started work in the organisation.

If the employee has left and was then re-employed, the start date should be the date they were re-employed.

This date would not change due to lateral moves or internal promotion within the organisation.

For example, April 2025 would be entered as: 04 2025.

answers.label: Employee start date

blocks.page_title: Employee start date

title.text: On {reference_date}, what was the full and specific job title for {employee_employeename}’s main job?

contents.description: Include:
Exclude:

list: internal works numbers or internal abbreviations

definitions.title: Examples of full and specific job titles

answers.label: Employee full and specific job title

blocks.page_title: Employee full and specific job title

title.text: Briefly describe what {employee_employeename} did in their main job

description: For example, if ’driver’ was stated in the previous question, specify the type of driver. For example, ’HGV driver’.

answers.label: Employee duties

blocks.page_title: Employee main job description

No, they did not work in the same job for more than a year

definitions.title: What we mean by ’employed on a permanent basis’

contents.description: This refers to a contract that has no fixed end date and remains valid until either employer or employee choose to end the contract.

No, they were not employed on a permanent basis

No, they were not on this type of contract

description: For example, if the employee was on a term time contract, such as a teacher not working school holidays, and their payments were spread over 52 weeks or 12 months.

options.label: Yes, they were paid on a pro rata basis
No, they were not paid on a pro rata basis

No, they did not have direct supervisory or managerial control of others
Information not available

blocks.page_title: Employee directory supervisory or managerial control

contents.description: This refers to paid jobs that incorporate on- and off-the-job training as part of a recognised apprenticeship framework, leading to nationally recognised qualifications.

options.label: Yes, they were an apprentice
No, they were not an apprentice

the postcode is not the employee’s usual local site or office

contents.description: This refers to the employee’s main place of work and not a central or head office address. You can give a central or head office address if the employee has no specified base.
If the employee is a remote or home worker we would expect the work postcode to be for the location they would report to or the closest main office site.

contents.description: Postcode information is important to the publication of the Annual Survey of Hours and Earnings (ASHE) results as it allows the Office for National Statistics (ONS) to generate earnings statistics for different geographic breakdowns.

If the employee is a remote or home worker we would expect the work postcode to be for the location they would report to or the closest main office site.

For example, if the employee is paid on the same date every month then the pay period is calendar month.

title.text: How much basic pay, before deductions, did {employee_employeename} earn for work carried out in the pay period that included {reference_date}?

contents.description: Include:

contents.description: Exclude:

the value of salary sacrifice schemes and benefits in kind

blocks.page_title: Basic pay earned for work carried out in pay period

options.label: Yes, this is correct
No, I need to change this
options.value: No, I need to change this

blocks.page_title: Basic pay confirmation

==: No, I need to change this

title.text: How many hours and minutes does this {basic_pay_earned_for_work_carried_out_in_the_pay_period} basic pay relate to, for work carried out in the pay period that included {reference_date}?

description:
Answer in full hours and minutes. For example, report 30 minutes instead of 0.5 hours.

If the pay period is calendar month and hours are weekly, multiply the weekly hours by 4.348 to get calendar month hours.

For example, if the given pay period is monthly, and the employee works 35 hours per week then report 152 hours 11 minutes. 35 multiplied by 4.348 equals 152.18, and 0.18 multiplied by 60 equals 10.8. 10.8 rounded up to nearest full minute is 11, therefore monthly hours is 152 hours 11 minutes.

If a decimal clock is used, convert to hours and minutes. For example, 4.3 hours should be recorded as 4 hours 18 minutes; 0.3 multiplied by 60 equals 18.

contents.description: Include:

list: any hours paid at shift premium and paid hours even if not worked

contents.description: Exclude:

answers.label: Hours
answers.description: Enter a whole number. Where the value is known to be nil, please write a single zero.

answers.label: Minutes
answers.description: Enter a whole number between 0 and 59. Where the value is known to be nil, please write a single zero.

blocks.page_title: Basic pay hours and minutes

title.text: How much overtime pay did {employee_employeename} receive for work carried out in the pay period that included {reference_date}?

contents.description: Exclude:

list: any basic, shift premium and bonus or incentive pay in this period
overtime pay from the previous pay period

answers.label: Overtime pay received for work carried out in the pay period
answers.description: Enter the full value in pounds and pence to 2 decimal places (for example, 56,234.33). Where the value is known to be nil, please write a single zero. If the value is unknown please leave blank.

blocks.page_title: Overtime pay received for work carried out in pay period

title.text: How many hours and minutes does this overtime pay relate to, for work carried out in the pay period that included {reference_date}?

description:
Answer in full hours and minutes. For example, report 30 minutes instead of 0.5 hours.

If a decimal clock is used, convert to hours and minutes. For example, 4.3 hours should be recorded as 4 hours 18 minutes (0.3 multiplied by 60 equals 18).

contents.description: Include:

list: the actual number of hours, for example, for 4 hours paid at time and a half, enter 4, not 6
any paid meal breaks taken during a period of overtime

contents.description: Exclude:

list: any hours paid at the basic or shift premium rate

answers.label: Hours
answers.description: Enter a whole number. Where the value is known to be nil, please write a single zero. If the value is unknown please leave blank.

answers.label: Minutes
answers.description: Enter a whole number between 0 and 59. Where the value is known to be nil, please write a single zero. If the value is unknown please leave blank.

blocks.page_title: Overtime pay hours and minutes

title.text: How much shift premium pay did {employee_employeename} receive in the pay period that included {reference_date}?

contents.description: Include:

list: the element of shift premium pay only

contents.description: Exclude:

list: any basic, overtime and bonus or incentive pay

definitions.title: How you might answer this question

contents.description: For example, for a 35 hour pay period, if the basic rate is £10 per hour and the premium rate is £12 per hour, multiply the difference of £2 by the hours worked. For example, 35 multiplied by 2. The shift premium pay reported would therefore be £70.

answers.label: Shift premium pay received in the pay period
answers.description: Enter the full value in pounds and pence to 2 decimal places (for example, 56,234.33). Where the value is known to be nil, please write a single zero. If the value is unknown please leave blank.

blocks.page_title: Shift premium pay received in pay period

title.text: How much bonus or incentive payments did {employee_employeename} receive in the pay period that included {reference_date}?

contents.description: Include:

list: profit sharing, productivity, performance and other bonus or incentive pay

contents.description: Exclude:

list: basic, overtime and shift premium pay

answers.label: Bonus or incentive payments received in the pay period
answers.description: Enter the full value in pounds and pence to 2 decimal places (for example, 56,234.33). Where the value is known to be nil, please write a single zero. If the value is unknown please leave blank.

blocks.page_title: Bonus or incentive payments received in pay period

title.text: How much of the bonus or incentive payments related to work carried out in the pay period that included {reference_date}?

definitions.title: How you might answer this question

contents.description: For example, if the bonus reported in the previous question was for a full year, the value should be divided by 12 if the employee was paid on a calendar month basis.

answers.label: Amount of bonus or incentive pay relating to work carried in the pay period
answers.description: Enter the full value in pounds and pence to 2 decimal places (for example, 56,234.33). Where the value is known to be nil, please write a single zero. If the value is unknown please leave blank.

blocks.page_title: Bonus or incentive payments related to work carried out in pay period

title.text: How much pay did {employee_employeename} receive for other reasons for work carried out in the pay period that included {reference_date}?

contents.description: Include:

list: paid allowances, for example, car allowances paid through the payroll, on call and standby allowances, clothing, first aider or fire fighter allowances

contents.description: Exclude:

list: paid leave such as holiday pay
basic, overtime, shift premium, maternity, paternity, sick, bonus or incentive pay

answers.label: Amount of pay for other reasons received in the pay period
answers.description: Enter the full value in pounds and pence to 2 decimal places (for example, 56,234.33). Where the value is known to be nil, please write a single zero. If the value is unknown please leave blank.

blocks.page_title: Pay received for other reasons for work carried out in pay period

question.title: Please specify what the amount of pay received for other reasons relates to
description: This question is optional. Leave blank if unknown.

answers.label: Pay received for other reasons comments

blocks.page_title: Other pay explanation

title.text: How much gross pay, before deductions, did {employee_employeename} receive for work carried out in the pay period that included {reference_date}?

description: If the employee has not received any additional pay, the gross pay will likely be the same as the basic pay previously reported.

contents.description: Include:

list: pay before deductions for PAYE, National Insurance, pension schemes, student loan repayments and voluntary deductions
basic, overtime, shift premium, bonus or incentive pay and any other pay

contents.description: Exclude:

list: expenses and the value of salary sacrifice schemes

answers.label: Gross pay, before deductions, received for work carried out in the pay period
answers.description: Enter the full value in pounds and pence to 2 decimal places (for example, 56,234.33). Where the value is known to be nil, please write a single zero. If the value is unknown please leave blank.

blocks.page_title: Gross pay received for work carried out in pay period

title.text: Was {employee_employeename} contracted on an hourly rate of pay, which when not impacted by sickness or special leave, is multiplied by hours worked to calculate basic pay?

No, their basic pay was not calculated in this way

title.text: On {reference_date}, what was {employee_employeename}’s main type of pension scheme?

description.text:
Employee name: {employee_employeename}

National Insurance Number: {employee_nationalinsurancenumberstarred}

Works number, branch, department: {employee_workid}

For all remaining questions on pensions, your answer should relate to the pay period that included {reference_date}.

contents.description: Include:

list: any of the following pensions, set up, or facilitated, but not run by the organisation or employer, or if the employer or employee is currently on a contributions holiday

contents.description: Exclude:

list: any private pension schemes set up by the individual, not facilitated by the organisation or employer

contents.description: This refers to Occupational Pension Schemes that are set up by employers to provide pensions and/or life assurance benefits for employees when they retire from work.
View further guidance on pension schemes (this link opens in a new tab).

options.label: Defined benefit
options.description: Run by the organisation, benefits are determined by the scheme rules, for example based on final or average salary.

options.label: National Employment Savings Trust (NEST)
Defined contribution (excluding NEST)
options.description: Run by the organisation, benefits are determined by contributions and investment returns, also known as money purchase.

options.label: Group personal pension
options.description: Facilitated but not run by the organisation, an arrangement made for employees to participate in a personal pension scheme on a grouped basis.

options.label: Group stakeholder pension
options.description: Facilitated but not run by the organisation, an arrangement made for employees to participate in a stakeholder pension scheme on a grouped basis.

options.label: Group Self Invested Personal Pension (SIPP)
options.description: Facilitated but not run by the organisation, an arrangement made for employees to participate in a SIPP on a grouped basis.

options.label: The employee does not pay into any of the pension schemes mentioned
options.description: For example, the employee opted out or pays into a private pension.

blocks.page_title: Main type of pension scheme

title.text: For the pay period that included {reference_date}, how much did the employer contribute to {employee_employeename}’s pension?

description.text:
If {employee_employeename}’s earnings have dropped below the lower earnings limit for Automatic Enrolment, please write a single zero.

Convert percentages of pensionable pay to monetary values.

contents.description: Exclude:

list: any lump sum contributions that cover more than one employee
any employee contributions made through salary sacrifice

definitions.title: How you might answer this question

contents.description: Convert any annual figures to the pay period previously provided. For example, to convert an annual figure where the pay period is weekly, divide the annual figure by 52.14, the precise number of weeks in a year.

If the contribution is a percentage, convert to a monetary value by multiplying the employee’s pensionable pay by the percentage. For example, if an employee has a percentage contribution of 3.5% and a pensionable pay monthly of £1,200, the employee contribution is £1,200 multiplied by 3.5%, which is £42 per month.

answers.label: Employer contributions to the employee’s pension in the pay period
answers.description: Enter the full value in pounds and pence to 2 decimal places (for example, 56,234.33). Where the value is known to be nil, please write a single zero. If the value is unknown please leave blank.

blocks.page_title: Employer contribution to pension in pay period

description.text:
If {employee_employeename}’s earnings have dropped below the lower earnings limit for Automatic Enrolment, please write a single zero.

Convert percentages of pensionable pay to monetary values.

contents.description: Include:

list: normal employee pension contributions made through salary sacrifice

contents.description: Exclude:

definitions.title: How you might answer this question

contents.description: Convert any annual figures to the pay period previously provided. For example, to convert an annual figure where the pay period is weekly, divide the annual figure by 52.14, the precise number of weeks in a year.

If the contribution is a percentage, convert to a monetary value by multiplying the employee’s pensionable pay by the percentage. For example, if an employee has a percentage contribution of 3.5% and a pensionable pay monthly of £1,200, the employee contribution is £1,200 multiplied by 3.5%, which is £42 per month.

answers.label: Employee contributions to their pension in the pay period
answers.description: Enter the full value in pounds and pence to 2 decimal places (for example, 56,234.33). Where the value is known to be nil, please write a single zero. If the value is unknown please leave blank.

If {employee_employeename}’s earnings have dropped below the lower earnings limit for Automatic Enrolment, please write a single zero.

Convert percentages of pensionable pay to monetary values.

definitions.title: How you might answer this question

contents.description: Convert any annual figures to the pay period previously provided. For example, to convert an annual figure where the pay period is weekly, divide the annual figure by 52.14, the precise number of weeks in a year.

If the contribution is a percentage, convert to a monetary value by multiplying the employee’s pensionable pay by the percentage. For example, if an employee has a percentage contribution of 3.5% and a pensionable pay monthly of £1,200, the employee contribution is £1,200 multiplied by 3.5%, which is £42 per month.

answers.label: Pensionable pay for the pay period
answers.description: Enter the full value in pounds and pence to 2 decimal places (for example, 56,234.33). Where the value is known to be nil, please write a single zero. If the value is unknown please leave blank.

title.text: For the pay period that included {reference_date}, were employee contributions made through a salary sacrifice arrangement?

description: This question is optional. Leave blank if unknown.

definitions.title: What we mean by ’salary sacrifice arrangement’

contents.description: This refers to a scheme where an employee agrees to receive goods or services in place of some of their basic pay. The employee agrees to new employment terms with a new level of basic pay.
The goods and services received can be any non-cash benefit, but common examples include:

options.label: Yes, contributions were made through a salary sacrifice arrangement
No, contributions were not made through a salary sacrifice arrangement

blocks.page_title: Employee contributions through salary sacrifice in pay period

title.text: For the tax year ending {tax_year_end_date}, how much of the annual gross pay is related to bonus or incentive payments for their current job?

contents.description: Include:

contents.description: Exclude:

list: basic, overtime and shift premium pay

answers.label: Amount of annual gross pay relating to bonus or incentive payments
answers.description: Enter the full value in pounds and pence to 2 decimal places (for example, 56,234.33). Where the value is known to be nil, please write a single zero. If the value is unknown please leave blank.

blocks.page_title: Annual pay relating to bonus or incentives in tax year

title.text: For the tax year ending {tax_year_end_date}, did {employee_employeename} receive any benefits in kind?

description: This question is optional. Leave blank if unknown.

options.label: Yes, they received benefits in kind
No, they did not receive any benefits in kind

blocks.page_title: Benefits in kind for the tax year

title.text: For the tax year ending {tax_year_end_date}, what was the value of the benefits in kind received?

description: If exact figures are not available, please provide informed estimates.

answers.label: Value of benefits in kind received
answers.description: Enter the full value in pounds and pence to 2 decimal places (for example, 56,234.33). Where the value is known to be nil, please write a single zero. If the value is unknown please leave blank.

blocks.page_title: Value of benefits in kind for the tax year

title.text: What is {employee_employeename}’s paid annual leave entitlement in days?

description.text:
Employee name: {employee_employeename}

National Insurance Number: {employee_nationalinsurancenumberstarred}

Works number, branch, department: {employee_workid}

If the annual leave is recorded in hours, please convert to the equivalent number of days.

contents.description: Exclude public and bank holidays

answers.label: Paid annual leave entitlement in days
answers.description: Enter the number of days to 1 decimal place. For example, if the employee is entitled to 25 days paid annual leave, then enter: 25.0 days.

blocks.page_title: Paid annual leave entitlement in days

title.text: For the tax year ending {tax_year_end_date}, was {employee_employeename}’s pay set with reference to an agreement affecting more than one employee?

description.text:
Employee name: {employee_employeename}

National Insurance Number: {employee_nationalinsurancenumberstarred}

Works number, branch, department: {employee_workid}

For example, pay may be agreed collectively by a trade union or workers’ committee.

options.label: Yes, their pay was set to an agreement affecting more than one employee
No, their pay was not set to an agreement affecting more than one employee

blocks.page_title: Pay agreement affecting multiple employees for tax year

title.text: For the tax year ending {tax_year_end_date}, what type of pay agreement was made for {employee_employeename}’s pay?

options.label: National or industry
options.description: This refers to an agreement at UK level, or an agreement for a particular industry as a whole; this is the most common type of agreement and exists mostly for occupations such as teachers, health professionals and protective service occupations.

options.label: Organisational
options.description: This refers to a single employer agreement that covers some or all of its employees; this type of agreement is common in retail and sales companies and general administrative occupations.

options.label: Sub-national
options.description: This refers to an agreement at regional level, which can cover more than one employer and more than one industry; this type of agreement is rare but exists for some public service professionals, childcare services and teaching occupations.

options.label: Workplace
options.description: This refers to an agreement applying only to employees in one workplace or site; agricultural occupations and transport companies sometimes have this type of agreement.

options.label: National or industry, supplemented by a sub-national, organisational or workplace agreement

blocks.page_title: Type of pay agreement for tax year

title.text: Has {employee_employeename} ever been employed by the organisation?

description.text:
Employee name: {employee_employeename}

National Insurance Number: {employee_nationalinsurancenumberstarred}

Works number, branch, department: {employee_workid}

options.label: Yes, they have been employed by the organisation
No, they have never been employed by the organisation

blocks.page_title: Employee’s employment history at your organisation

title.text: Has {employee_employeename} left the organisation?

options.label: Yes, they have left the organisation
No, they have not left the organisation

title.text: When did {employee_employeename} leave the organisation?

description: For example, April 2025 would be entered as: 04 2025.

answers.label: Date they left the organisation

question.title: Please provide any further details that will help us to understand the information you have supplied
description:
Any additional information given in the comments may enable us to process your submission without needing to contact you.

This question is optional. Leave blank if not applicable.

a breakdown of salary sacrifice values
the employee was on long term sick leave
employee has retired therefore did not work
